Laura_Benanti:
{{Short description|American actress and singer (born 1979)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2024}} {{Infobox person | name = Laura Benanti | image = Laura Benanti cropped.jpg | caption = Benanti in 2012 Drama League Benefit Gala | birthname = Laura Ilene Vidnovic | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|7|15}} | birth_place = New York City, U.S. | occupation = Actress, singer | yearsactive = 1998–present | credits = {{unbulleted list | ''[[Gypsy (musical)|Gypsy]]'' | ''[[Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown (musical)|Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown]]''}} | spouse = {{unbulleted list | {{marriage|[[Chris Barron]]
|2005|2006|reason=divorced}} | {{marriage|[[Steven Pasquale]]
|2007|2013|reason=divorced}} | {{marriage|Patrick Brown
|2015}}}} | children = 2 | website = {{official URL}} }} '''Laura Ilene Benanti''' ([[née]] '''Vidnovic'''; born July 15, 1979) {{cite web |url=https://pantagraph.com/image_7f302ff2-96c8-515b-8c1a-2ff386a794b5.html |title=Birthday: Laura Benanti |date=July 15, 2015}} is an American actress and singer. Benanti made her [[Broadway (theatre)|Broadway]] debut as an ensemble member and later as [[Maria von Trapp]] in the 1998 revival of ''[[The Sound of Music]]''. Benanti went on to win the [[Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Musical]] playing [[Gypsy Rose Lee|Louise]] in the revival of ''[[Gypsy (musical)|Gypsy]]'' (2008). She was Tony-nominated for her roles in ''[[Swing!]]'' (2000), ''[[Into the Woods]]'' (2002), ''[[Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown (musical)|Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown]]'' (2010), and ''[[She Loves Me]]'' (2016). Her other notable Broadway roles include in ''[[Nine (musical)|Nine]]'' (2003), ''[[In the Next Room (or The Vibrator Play)|In the Next Room]]'' (2009), ''[[Meteor Shower (play)|Meteor Shower]]'' (2017), and ''[[My Fair Lady]]'' (2018). On television she has had roles as Lauren Bennett on the [[NBC]] sitcom ''[[Go On (TV series)|Go On]]'' (2012–2013), Sadie Stone in the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] musical drama series ''[[Nashville (2012 TV series)|Nashville]]'' (2014–2015), [[Alura (DC Comics)|Alura]] and Astra in the [[CBS]] series ''[[Supergirl (TV series)|Supergirl]]'' (2015–2016), Edie Randall in the [[TBS (American TV channel)|TBS]] comedy ''[[The Detour (TV series)|The Detour]]'' (2017–2019), Kiki Hope in the [[HBO Max]] revival ''[[Gossip Girl (2021 TV series)|Gossip Girl]]'' (2021–2023) and as Susan Blane in the HBO drama series ''[[The Gilded Age (TV series)|The Gilded Age]]'' (2023). Since 2016, she has had a recurring role as [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]] [[Melania Trump]] on ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]]''. ==Early life== Benanti was born in New York City to Linda Wonneberger, a vocal coach and former actress, and [[Martin Vidnovic]], a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] actor and singer.Rosati, Nancy. [http://www.talkinbroadway.com/spot/benanti1.html "Spotlight on Laura Benanti"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061030221320/http://www.talkinbroadway.com/spot/benanti1.html |date=October 30, 2006}}, Talkin' Broadway, 2000. Retrieved on June 29, 2008. She is of Serbian,{{Cite web |last=Markovic |first=Kristina |date=July 13, 2023 |title=Glumice za koje niste imali pojma da su srpskog porekla |url=https://zadovoljna.nova.rs/poznati/glumice-za-koje-niste-imali-pojma-da-su-srpskog-porekla/ |access-date=July 14, 2023 |website=Zadovoljna |language=sr-RS}} German, and Irish heritage.{{Cite web|last=Buckley|first=Michael|date=August 28, 2005|title=Stage to Screens: Chatting with Stage and Screen Star Laura Benanti|url=https://www.playbill.com/article/stage-to-screens-chatting-with-stage-and-screen-star-laura-benanti-com-127680|access-date=December 20, 2020|website=Playbill}} Her parents divorced when she was young. She soon moved to [[Kinnelon, New Jersey]], with her mother and stepfather Salvatore Benanti, a [[psychotherapist]], whose name she took and whom she refers to as her father.Singer, Barry. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A02E4DF1E3CF93BA15752C0A9679C8B63 "Theater; With a Song in Her Heart, Taking On the Stage (Again)"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200926224330/https://www.nytimes.com/2001/01/28/theater/theater-with-a-song-in-her-heart-taking-on-the-stage-again.html |date=September 26, 2020}}, ''[[The New York Times]]'', January 28, 2001. Retrieved on June 29, 2008. Benanti remembers being "very serious" and "a bit of an [[ugly duckling]]" as a child; she was intensely interested in [[musical theatre]], saying she "came out of the womb as a 40-year-old". She was particularly interested in the music of [[Stephen Sondheim]] at an early age and distanced herself from other children.McGee, Celia. [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/23/theater/23mcge.html "Sing Out, Laura. It's Your Turn."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170207134511/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/23/theater/23mcge.html |date=February 7, 2017}}, ''[[The New York Times]]'', March 23, 2008. Retrieved on June 29, 2008. In 2008, Benanti told ''The New York Times'' that she drew on this loneliness in her portrayal of the neglected Louise in ''[[Gypsy: A Musical Fable|Gypsy]]''. Though her parents refused to let Laura audition for professional theatre, Laura appeared in several high school and community productions, including ''[[Evita (musical)|Evita]]'' (as [[Juan Perón|Perón]]'s mistress), ''[[Follies]]'' (as Young Heidi), and ''[[Into the Woods]]'' (as [[Cinderella]]). At 16, Benanti played the title role in her high school production of ''[[Hello, Dolly! (musical)|Hello, Dolly!]]'' and won a [[Paper Mill Playhouse]] Rising Star Award for Outstanding Actress in a high school production.Klein, Alvin. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE1DD123BF933A15755C0A96F958260 "Jersey Footlights; A Girl Named Maria"], ''[[The New York Times]]''; retrieved June 30, 2008. She graduated from [[Kinnelon High School]] in 1997. ==Career== ===1998–2006: Broadway debut and early roles === In 1998, [[Paper Mill Playhouse|Paper Mill]]'s then-artistic director Robert Johanson recommended Benanti for the role of Liesl in a Broadway revival of ''[[The Sound of Music]]''. She auditioned for the show's producers and was considered too mature-looking to play Liesl, but, after several call-backs, was signed at the age of 18 to play one of the nuns and to understudy [[Rebecca Luker]] as Maria. Benanti played the role for two weeks while Luker was on vacation, and, at 19, took over the role when Luker left the production. Michael Buckley of ''[[Playbill]]'' later wrote that Benanti "was an absolutely wonderful Maria ... As do others, I believe that had she opened in the show, Benanti would have been an overnight sensation." When she was cast in ''The Sound of Music'', Benanti had attended [[New York University]] for two weeks; the dean recommended she go on leave to take the job.Fradkin, Lori. [https://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2008/03/laura_benanti_on_stripping_in.html "Laura Benanti on Stripping in 'Gypsy' and Her Delighted Husband"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521205552/http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2008/03/laura_benanti_on_stripping_in.html |date=May 21, 2011}}, ''[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]'', March 28, 2008; retrieved June 30, 2008. In 1999, Benanti appeared in the Broadway revue ''[[Swing!]]'', for which she received a [[Tony Award|Tony]] nomination for [[Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Musical|Best Performance by a Featured Actress in a Musical]]. In 2000, she co-starred with [[Donna Murphy]] in the critically acclaimed [[New York City Center]] [[Encores!]] concert production of the [[Leonard Bernstein]]-[[Betty Comden]]-[[Adolph Green]] musical ''[[Wonderful Town]]''. Benanti can be heard on the original cast albums of each of her Broadway roles, as well as compilation albums of [[Stephen Schwartz (composer)|Stephen Schwartz]] and [[Maury Yeston]]. She participated in a [[studio cast recording]] of [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]]'s ''[[Allegro (musical)|Allegro]]'', which was released by [[Sony Classics]] in February 2009. She also appears as a guest artist on the [[Gay Men's Chorus of Washington, D.C.]]'s live album, ''You've Got to Be Carefully Taught: The Songs of Hammerstein & Sondheim'', taken from a 2002 performance at the [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts|Kennedy Center]]. A songwriter and guitarist, Benanti has written songs privately since at least the early 2000s; in 2005, she said that she was working on a folk-rock solo CD, though "Musical theatre is my first love[...]I want to take my music and orchestrate it in a kind of old fashioned style, and take some standards and 'popularize' them—do a true crossover. I'm working on it." In 2002, Benanti played [[Cinderella]] (a role she had played as a teenager) in the Broadway revival of ''[[Into the Woods]]'' and received both a Tony nomination for Best Performance by a Featured Actress in a Musical and a [[Drama Desk Award|Drama Desk]] nomination for [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Featured Actress in a Musical|Outstanding Featured Actress in a Musical]]. During a mid-performance [[Physical comedy|pratfall]] in ''Into the Woods'', Benanti fractured her neck, herniating two discs directly onto her [[spinal cord]] and cutting off [[spinal fluid]], a condition that sometimes leads to [[paralysis]]. The injury was misdiagnosed, and ''Into the Woods'' producers asked Benanti not to mention her injury; when she began missing performances due to neck problems, rumors spread that Benanti was behaving unprofessionally, something that she called "really hurtful". She said, "I had a serious injury and there was absolutely no way I could have done the show. I tried to. I tried to go back and do it but I physically couldn't."Rosati, Nancy. [http://www.talkinbroadway.com/spot/benantiupdate.html "Update Interview with Laura Benanti"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061029232407/http://www.talkinbroadway.com/spot/benantiupdate.html |date=October 29, 2006}}, Talkin' Broadway, 2006. Retrieved on June 30, 2008. Benanti was eventually replaced in the show by [[Erin Dilly]]. Eight months after her initial injury, Benanti was rediagnosed and received surgery that could have damaged her voice but was successful, though as of 2005 she still experienced neck pain and [[myelopathy]]. Three weeks after undergoing spinal surgery, Benanti started previews in March 2003 for the Broadway revival of ''[[Nine (musical)|Nine]]'', in which she played Claudia, a movie star who inspires Guido, a director played by [[Antonio Banderas]]. She left the show in September 2003. Benanti appeared in the [[World AIDS Day]] concerts of ''[[Pippin (musical)|Pippin]]'', ''[[Children of Eden]]'', and ''[[The Secret Garden (musical)|The Secret Garden]]''.Jones, Kenneth. [http://www.playbill.com/article/benanti-murney-harada-lewis-star-in-children-of-eden-benefit-concert-dec-1-in-nyc-com-116409 "Benanti, Murney, Harada, Lewis Star in Children of Eden Benefit Concert, Dec. 1 in NYC"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805052443/http://www.playbill.com/article/benanti-murney-harada-lewis-star-in-children-of-eden-benefit-concert-dec-1-in-nyc-com-116409 |date=August 5, 2016}} Playbill.com, November 18, 2003.Murray, Matthew. [http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/11-2004/full-cast-announced-for-pippin-concert-to-benefit-_5292.html "Full Cast Announced for Pippin Concert to Benefit National AIDS Fund"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160809035517/http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/11-2004/full-cast-announced-for-pippin-concert-to-benefit-_5292.html |date=August 9, 2016}} Theatermania.com, November 1, 2004.Portantiere, Michael. [http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/10-2005/arden-benanti-keenan-bolger-mann-et-al-will-perfor_6890.html "Arden, Benanti, Keenan-Bolger, Mann, et al. Will Perform The Secret Garden in Concert for World AIDS Day"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160809052830/http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/10-2005/arden-benanti-keenan-bolger-mann-et-al-will-perfor_6890.html |date=August 9, 2016}} Theatermania.com, October 12, 2005. From April to December 2006, she played Julia Sullivan in the Broadway musical ''[[The Wedding Singer (musical)|The Wedding Singer]]''.Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/103001.html "The Wedding Is Off: New Musical ''Wedding Singer'' to Close in December"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061108172433/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/103001.html |date=November 8, 2006}}, Playbill.com, October 25, 2006. Retrieved on June 29, 2008. In addition to stage roles, Benanti was a regular on the short-lived [[FX Networks|FX]] sitcom ''[[Starved]]'' (2005), which received mixed reviews,Gerhart, Ann. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/08/03/AR2005080302134.html "FX's 'Starved' Is a Bit Too Much To Stomach"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170926190800/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/08/03/AR2005080302134.html |date=September 26, 2017}} ''Washington Post'', August 4, 2005Osterweil, Neil. [http://www.cnn.com/2005/HEALTH/conditions/08/04/starved/ "Is there appetite for eating disorders sitcom?"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307114224/http://www.cnn.com/2005/HEALTH/conditions/08/04/starved/ |date=March 7, 2016}} ''CNN'', August 5, 2005 but Benanti described it as "a good experience. I got a lot of camera experience, which was something I just hadn't had." In 2006, she appeared in two films: ''[[Take the Lead]]'', in which she reunited with her ''Nine'' co-star Antonio Banderas,[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/629222/Take-the-Lead/ ''Take the Lead''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303142216/http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/629222/Take-the-Lead/ |date=March 3, 2016}} tcm.com, accessed January 20, 2016 and ''[[Falling for Grace]]'' as Princess Alexandra.[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/642739/Falling-for-Grace/ ''Falling for Grace''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303135153/http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/642739/Falling-for-Grace/ |date=March 3, 2016}} tcm.com, accessed January 20, 2016[https://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/347386/Falling-for-Grace/cast "'Falling for Grace' Cast"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305164102/http://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/347386/Falling-for-Grace/cast |date=March 5, 2016}} ''New York Times'', accessed January 20, 2016 In 2008, Benanti had a recurring role on the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] television series ''[[Eli Stone]]''. She appeared in the pilot for the TV show as well.Hernandez, Ernio. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/wedding-singer-star-laura-benanti-cast-in-abc-pilot-eli-stone-136593# "''Wedding Singer'' Star Laura Benanti Cast in ABC Pilot 'Eli Stone'"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604093926/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/wedding-singer-star-laura-benanti-cast-in-abc-pilot-eli-stone-136593|date=June 4, 2016}} playbill.com, November 22, 2006Gertel, Elliot B. [http://www.jewishworldreview.com/elliot/gertel_eli_stone.php3 "'Eli Stone': Self-indulgent, arrogant corporate attorney as modern-day prophet"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150920234243/http://jewishworldreview.com/elliot/gertel_eli_stone.php3 |date=September 20, 2015}} ''Jewish World Review'', July 22, 2008 === 2007–2015: ''Gypsy'' and acclaim === In July 2007, Benanti played in a three-week limited run of the musical ''[[Gypsy: A Musical Fable|Gypsy]]'' in the Encores! staged concert production at the [[New York City Center]] as Louise, alongside [[Patti LuPone]] as Rose and [[Boyd Gaines]] as Herbie. In March 2008, the production transferred to Broadway, where it ran until January 2009 and received widespread critical acclaim. Benanti's performance as Louise was praised, with ''[[The New York Times]]''{{'}}s [[Ben Brantley]] declaring it "the performance of her career".Brantley, Ben. [http://theater2.nytimes.com/2008/03/28/theater/reviews/28gyps.html "Curtain Up! It's Patti's Turn at 'Gypsy'"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080626231507/http://theater2.nytimes.com/2008/03/28/theater/reviews/28gyps.html |date=June 26, 2008}}, ''[[The New York Times]]'', March 3, 2008. Retrieved on June 29, 2008. She won several awards, including a Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Musical, a Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Featured Actress in a Musical, and an [[Outer Critics Circle Award]] for Outstanding Featured Actress in a Musical. Benanti appeared in [[The Public Theater]]'s world-premiere production of [[Christopher Durang]]'s play ''Why Torture Is Wrong, And the People Who Love Them'' from April 6 to 26, 2009.{{Cite web|last=Itzkoff|first=Dave|date=February 12, 2009|title=Anne Hathaway to Star in 'Twelfth Night' in the Park|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/13/theater/13arts-ANNEHATHAWAY_BRF.html|access-date=February 15, 2009|website=The New York Times}} She next appeared in the [[Lincoln Center Theater]]'s production of [[Sarah Ruhl]]'s ''[[In the Next Room (or The Vibrator Play)]]'' beginning previews on October 22, 2009, and opening on November 19, 2009, at the [[Lyceum Theatre (Broadway)|Lyceum Theatre]].{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=In the Next Room|url=https://www.playbill.com/production/in-the-next-room-lyceum-theatre-vault-0000007079|access-date=December 20, 2020|website=Playbill}} Benanti appeared in the new musical ''[[Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown (musical)|Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown]]'' on Broadway from October 8, 2010, until January 2, 2011. She received a Tony nomination and won the Drama Desk and Outer Critics Circle Awards for Best Featured Actress in a Musical for her performance.[http://broadwayworld.com/article/2011-Tony-Nominations-Announced-THE-BOOK-OF-MORMON-Leads-With-14-20110503 "Tony Nominations Announced"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110507015850/http://broadwayworld.com/article/2011-Tony-Nominations-Announced-THE-BOOK-OF-MORMON-Leads-With-14-20110503 |date=May 7, 2011}} orders three dramas, including 'The Playboy Club'|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2011/05/12/locally-shot-the-playboy-club-series-picked-up-by-nbc/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120701164725/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-05-12/entertainment/chi-0512-nbc-playboy-drama-story_1_grimm-drama-mad-men|archive-date=July [[File:Curtain Call for the Radio City Music Hall New York Spring Spectacular (16711310200).jpg|thumb|right|Benanti with [[Derek Hough]] and Jared Grimes at the [[Radio City Music Hall]] Spring Spectacular in 2015]] In June 2013, Benanti performed as the soprano soloist in the San Francisco premiere of [[Andrew Lippa]]'s oratorio, ''I Am Harvey Milk''.{{Cite web|last=Hetrick|first=Adam|date=26 June 2013|title=''I Am Harvey Milk'', With Andrew Lippa and Laura Benanti, Premieres in San Francisco June 26|url=https://www.playbill.com/article/i-am-harvey-milk-with-andrew-lippa-and-laura-benanti-premieres-in-san-francisco-june-26-com-206961|access-date=December 20, 2020|website=Playbill}} She played Goddess in [[The Public Theater]]'s musical adaptation of ''[[The Tempest]]'', which was presented at the [[Delacorte Theatre]] from September 6 through 8, 2013.{{Cite web|last=Hetrick|first=Adam|date=August 7, 2013|title=Laura Benanti, Norm Lewis and More to Headline ''The Tempest'' at the Delacorte|url=https://www.playbill.com/article/laura-benanti-norm-lewis-and-more-to-headline-the-tempest-at-the-delacorte-com-208304|access-date=December 20, 2020|website=Playbill}} She had a recurring role on the [[USA Network|USA]] series ''[[Royal Pains]]''.Stanhope, Kate. March 10, 2014. On December 5, 2013, Benanti played Elsa Schräder in the NBC production of ''[[The Sound of Music Live!]]''{{Cite web|last=Gans|first=Andrew|date=September 16, 2013|title=Audra McDonald, Laura Benanti and Christian Borle Join Cast of NBC's ''Sound of Music''|url=https://playbill.com/article/audra-mcdonald-laura-benanti-and-christian-borle-join-cast-of-nbcs-sound-of-music-com-209565|access-date=December 20, 2020|website=Playbill}}[http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/09/16/sound-of-music-nbc-carrie-underwood-casting-poster 'Sound of Music Live!' with Carrie Underwood: NBC announces more cast, releases poster] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130919072719/http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/09/16/sound-of-music-nbc-carrie-underwood-casting-poster/ |date=September 19, 2013}}, Insidetv.ew.com; retrieved September 16, 2013. ''In Constant Search of the Right Kind of Attention'', a live recording of Benanti's concert engagement at [[54 Below]], was released by Broadway Records in September 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Broadway-Records-Will-Release-Live-Album-of-Laura-Benanti-at-54-Below-20130905 |title=Broadway Records Releases Live Album of Laura Benanti at 54 Below Today |website=Broadwayworld.com |date=September 10, 2013 |access-date=January 20, 2016 |archive-date=March 4, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304114449/http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Broadway-Records-Will-Release-Live-Album-of-Laura-Benanti-at-54-Below-20130905 |url-status=live}} In 2014, she was cast as country singer Sadie Stone in the ABC musical drama series ''[[Nashville (2012 TV series)|Nashville]]'' for its [[Nashville (season 3)|third season]], recording and performing several songs during her arc.{{cite web|url=https://www.deadline.com/2014/07/laura-benanti-joins-abcs-nashville-benjamin-ciaramello-in-secrets-lies/|title=Laura Benanti Joins ABC's 'Nashville'; Benjamin Ciaramello In 'Secrets & Lies'|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=July 30, 2014|access-date=July 31, 2014|archive-date=August 1, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140801074740/http://www.deadline.com/2014/07/laura-benanti-joins-abcs-nashville-benjamin-ciaramello-in-secrets-lies/|url-status=live}} From April 2 through 6, 2014, Benanti starred as Rosabella in the New York City Center Encores! staged concert production of [[Frank Loesser]]'s ''[[The Most Happy Fella]]'' alongside [[Shuler Hensley]], [[Cheyenne Jackson]], [[Jay Armstrong Johnson]], and [[Heidi Blickenstaff]].[http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/BREAKING-NEWS-Laura-Benanti-Cheyenne-Jackson-Shuler-Hensley-to-Lead-MOST-HAPPY-FELLA-at-Encores-Running-April-2-6-20130822 "Laura Benanti, Cheyenne Jackson & Shuler Hensley to Lead The Most Happy Fella at Encores!; Running April 2-6"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130825023216/http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/BREAKING-NEWS-Laura-Benanti-Cheyenne-Jackson-Shuler-Hensley-to-Lead-MOST-HAPPY-FELLA-at-Encores-Running-April-2-6-20130822 |date=August 25, 2013}} Broadwayworld.com, August 22, 2013 In 2015, she joined the cast of ''[[Supergirl (TV series)|Supergirl]]'', where she has a recurring role as [[Alura (DC Comics)|Alura In-Ze]], [[Zor-El]]'s wife and mother of [[Supergirl (Kara Zor-El)|Kara]]{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2015/02/laura-benanti-supergirl-mom-pilot-cbs-1201377441|title=Laura Benanti To Play Supergirl's Mom In Greg Berlanti's CBS Pilot|website=Deadline Hollywood|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|date=February 20, 2015|access-date=April 17, 2020|archive-date=September 26, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200926224330/https://deadline.com/2015/02/laura-benanti-supergirl-mom-pilot-greg-berlanti-cbs-1201377441/|url-status=live}} and Alura's twin sister [[List of Supergirl characters#Astra In-Ze|General Astra]], who wants to take over Earth as its new ruler and destroy her niece Kara.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.ew.com/article/2015/10/26/supergirl-season-1-spoilers-andrew-kreisberg|title=Supergirl postmortem: Get the scoop on that villain twist and what's next|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|last=Abrams|first=Natalie|date=October 26, 2015|access-date=October 26, 2015|archive-date=October 27, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151027222027/http://www.ew.com/article/2015/10/26/supergirl-season-1-spoilers-andrew-kreisberg|url-status=live}} In July 2017, it was announced that Benanti would not return to the series for its third season due to her work schedule and that [[Erica Durance]] would assume the role of Alura.{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2017/07/supergirl-erica-durance-alura-recasting-laura-benanti-1202125270/|title='Supergirl': Erica Durance To Take Over Alura Role From Laura Benanti|website=Deadline Hollywood|last=Petski|first=Denise|date=July 7, 2017|access-date=July 8, 2017|archive-date=July 10, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170710053217/http://deadline.com/2017/07/supergirl-erica-durance-alura-recasting-laura-benanti-1202125270/|url-status=live}} Benanti guest-starred as Edie, a [[United States Postal Service]] inspector, in the second season of ''[[The Detour (TV series)|The Detour]]'' and was later promoted to a series regular for season three.{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2017/07/31/the-detour-laura-benanti-season-3-edie-series-regular/|title=The Detour Promotes Laura Benanti to Series Regular Ahead of Season 3|website=[[TVLine]]|last=Roots|first=Kimberly|date=July 31, 2017|access-date=July 31, 2017|archive-date=July 31, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731231853/http://tvline.com/2017/07/31/the-detour-laura-benanti-season-3-edie-series-regular/|url-status=live}} On February 16, 2015, Benanti played Lucille Frank in the Manhattan Concert Productions presentation of ''[[Parade (musical)|Parade]]'' at [[Avery Fisher Hall]], alongside [[Jeremy Jordan (actor, born 1984)|Jeremy Jordan]] as [[Leo Frank]].Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/tony-winning-musical-parade-with-laura-benanti-and-jeremy-jordan-rises-again-341729 "Tony-Winning Musical Parade, With Laura Benanti and Jeremy Jordan, Rises Again"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216121739/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/tony-winning-musical-parade-with-laura-benanti-and-jeremy-jordan-rises-again-341729 |date=February 16, 2015}} Playbill.com, February 16, 2015. She appeared in ''New York Spring Spectacular'' at [[Radio City Music Hall]] from March 12 through May 7, 2015.Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/new-york-spring-spectacular-starring-laura-benanti-extends-run-346254 "''New York Spring Spectacular'', Starring Laura Benanti, Extends Run"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518081943/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/new-york-spring-spectacular-starring-laura-benanti-extends-run-346254|date=May 18, 2015}} Playbill.com, April 8, 2015. === 2016–present === [[File:First Lady Melania Trump at the Boston Medical Center (49030104293) (cropped).jpg|thumb|130px|Benanti has portrayed [[Melania Trump]] numerous times on ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]]'']] Benanti starred in the lead role of Amalia Balash in the 2016 [[Roundabout Theatre Company]] Broadway revival of ''[[She Loves Me]]'' opposite [[Zachary Levi]]. The production began previews at [[Studio 54]] on February 19, 2016, and opened on March 17 for a limited engagement through July 10.Gioia, Michael. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/laura-benanti-and-josh-radnor-will-star-in-broadway-revival-of-she-loves-me-339608 "Laura Benanti and Josh Radnor Will Star in Broadway Revival of She Loves Me"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626155702/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/laura-benanti-and-josh-radnor-will-star-in-broadway-revival-of-she-loves-me-339608 |date=June 26, 2015}} Playbill.com, January 20, 2015.Cox, Gordon. [https://variety.com/2015/legit/news/zachary-levi-broadway-she-loves-me-1201582742/ "Zachary Levi to Star in Broadway's 'She Loves Me'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171231212114/https://variety.com/2015/legit/news/zachary-levi-broadway-she-loves-me-1201582742/ |date=December 31, 2017}} Variety.com, September 1, 2015.Clement, Olivia. [http://www.playbill.com/article/she-loves-me-closes-on-broadway-tonight# "''She Loves Me'' Closes on Broadway Today"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160713214007/http://www.playbill.com/article/she-loves-me-closes-on-broadway-tonight|date=July 13, 2016}} Playbill, July 10, 2016 She received a nomination for [[Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical]] for this role. On July 19, 2016, Benanti first impersonated [[Melania Trump]] on ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]]'' during the run-up to that year's [[2016 United States presidential election|U.S. presidential election]],{{Cite web|last=Wright|first=Tolly|date=July 20, 2016|title=Laura Benanti Impersonates Melania Trump on The Late Show and It's Perfect|url=https://www.vulture.com/2016/07/laura-benantis-impersonation-of-melania-is-gold.html|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160720231449/http://www.vulture.com/2016/07/laura-benantis-impersonation-of-melania-is-gold.html|archive-date=July 20, 2016|access-date=July 20, 2016|website=[[Vulture (website)|Vulture]]}} a role she reprised in subsequent appearances on that show.{{cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/la-et-st-laura-benanti-melania-trump-20161019-snap-story.html|title=Laura Benanti reveals her method for impersonating Melania Trump|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|author=Villarreal, Yvonne|date=October 19, 2016|access-date=May 7, 2018|archive-date=January 2, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170102071208/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/la-et-st-laura-benanti-melania-trump-20161019-snap-story.html}} In 2017, Benanti once again acted on Broadway in [[Steve Martin]]'s comedic play ''[[Meteor Shower (play)|Meteor Shower]]'', along with [[Keegan-Michael Key]] as Gerald, [[Amy Schumer]] as Corky, and [[Jeremy Shamos]] as Norm. The play premiered on Broadway on November 1, 2017, in previews, officially on November 29, 2017, at the [[Booth Theatre]]. The play closed on January 21, 2018.McPhee, Ryan. [http://www.playbill.com/article/amy-schumer-and-laura-benanti-star-in-steve-martins-meteor-shower-beginning-on-broadway-november-1# "Steve Martin's ''Meteor Shower'', Starring Amy Schumer and Laura Benanti, Ends Broadway Run January 21"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180124005741/http://www.playbill.com/article/amy-schumer-and-laura-benanti-star-in-steve-martins-meteor-shower-beginning-on-broadway-november-1|date=January 24, 2018}} Playbill, January 21, 2018 Benanti replaced [[Lauren Ambrose]] as [[Eliza Doolittle]] in the Broadway Lincoln Center Theater revival of ''[[My Fair Lady]]'', beginning October 23, 2018, for a limited run through February 17, 2019, except for Tuesday nights with [[Kerstin Anderson]] in the role.{{Cite news|last=Paulson|first=Michael|date=August 23, 2018|title=Laura Benanti to Join 'My Fair Lady' on Broadway|language=en|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/23/theater/laura-benanti-my-fair-lady-broadway.html|url-status=live|access-date=August 23, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180823160511/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/23/theater/laura-benanti-my-fair-lady-broadway.html|archive-date=August 23, 2018}} Benanti extended her appearance in the musical to July 7, 2019.{{Cite web|last=Fierberg|first=Ruthie|date=February 11, 2019|title=Laura Benanti Extends Run in Broadway's ''My Fair Lady''|url=https://www.playbill.com/article/laura-benanti-extends-run-in-broadways-my-fair-lady#|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190212011038/http://www.playbill.com/article/laura-benanti-extends-run-in-broadways-my-fair-lady|archive-date=February 12, 2019|access-date=|website=Playbill}} In 2019, she joined the cast of ''[[Younger (TV Series)|Younger]]'', playing the role of businesswoman and author Quinn Tyler. Benanti released her self-titled first solo album in 2020.{{cite web|last=McPhee|first=Ryan|date=September 18, 2020|title=Laura Benanti to Release Debut Studio Album, Drops Single of Rufus Wainwright Cover|url=https://www.playbill.com/article/laura-benanti-to-release-debut-studio-album-drops-single-of-rufus-wainwright-cover|access-date=October 28, 2020|website=Playbill}} In 2021, Benanti played the role of Francine in the film ''[[Here Today (film)|Here Today]]'', co-written and directed by [[Billy Crystal]], starring Crystal and [[Tiffany Haddish]]. In 2023, she played the role of Allison Becker in ''[[No Hard Feelings (2023 film)|No Hard Feelings]]'', which starred [[Jennifer Lawrence]]. ==Personal life== Benanti met [[Chris Barron]], lead singer of the [[Spin Doctors]], in the early 2000s. They married on July 25, 2005, but by the end of that year were in the process of a divorce,{{cite web |author=Brian Scott Lipton |url=http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/06-2007/everythings-coming-up-laura_11043.html |title=Everything's Coming Up Laura |website=TheaterMania.com |date=June 26, 2007 |access-date=January 20, 2016 |archive-date=March 2, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160302135230/http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/06-2007/everythings-coming-up-laura_11043.html |url-status=live}} which was finalized in 2006. At the 2005 [[World AIDS Day]] "dream cast" concert of ''[[The Secret Garden (musical)|The Secret Garden]]'', she met actor [[Steven Pasquale]]. They married in September 2007 and mutually filed for divorce in July 2013.[http://www.newjerseybride.com/articles/an-off "An Off-Broadway Production"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100723071416/http://www.newjerseybride.com/articles/an-off |date=July 23, 2010}} Newjerseybride.com, December 17, 2008{{cite web |url=http://www.broadway.com/buzz/170502/broadway-stars-laura-benanti-steven-pasquale-to-divorce |title=Broadway Stars Laura Benanti & Steven Pasquale to Divorce | Broadway Buzz |website=Broadway.com |date=July 8, 2013 |access-date=January 20, 2016 |archive-date=April 13, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160413000754/http://www.broadway.com/buzz/170502/broadway-stars-laura-benanti-steven-pasquale-to-divorce/ |url-status=live}} On June 12, 2015, she became engaged to Patrick Brown.Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/put-a-ring-on-it-tony-winner-laura-benanti-is-engaged-351242 "Put a Ring On It! Tony Winner Laura Benanti Is Engaged"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710013043/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/put-a-ring-on-it-tony-winner-laura-benanti-is-engaged-351242 |date=July 10, 2015}} Playbill.com, June 12, 2015 They married on November 15, 2015.{{cite web |last=Adams |first=Char |url=http://www.people.com/article/laura-benanti-patrick-brown-married-supergirl |title=Supergirl's Laura Benanti and Patrick Brown |website=People.com |date=November 16, 2015 |access-date=January 20, 2016 |archive-date=March 4, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304104041/http://www.people.com/article/laura-benanti-patrick-brown-married-supergirl |url-status=live}} In 2017, they had a daughter, Ella.Fierberg, Ruthie. [http://www.playbill.com/article/laura-benanti-gives-birth-to-beautiful-and-healthy-baby-girl# "Laura Benanti Gives Birth to "Beautiful and Healthy" Baby Girl"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215100427/http://www.playbill.com/article/laura-benanti-gives-birth-to-beautiful-and-healthy-baby-girl |date=February 15, 2017}} Playbill, February 14, 2017 A second daughter, Louisa, was born via surrogate in 2022.{{Cite web |title=Laura Benanti Welcomes Baby via Surrogate and Shares Photos with Daughter Ella: 'Rainbow Babies' |url=https://people.com/parents/laura-benanti-welcomes-second-child-surrogate/ |access-date=March 9, 2023 |website=Peoplemag |language=en}} On April 7, 2023, Benanti announced that she had suffered a [[miscarriage]] while on stage at a Broadway themed cruise. Knowing she was having the miscarriage, she continued to perform saying that "if it had been our first loss, or even our second, I likely wouldn't have been able to go on […] but unfortunately I am not a stranger to the pain and emptiness of losing a pregnancy".{{Cite news |date=April 7, 2023 |title=Laura Benanti: Actress says she went on stage while having miscarriage |language=en-GB |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-65211625 |access-date=April 7, 2023}} == Filmography == ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !
